title: Average number of reoffences per criminal offender
measure_summary:
This data measures the average number of reoffences committed by criminal offenders in different ethnic groups. 

Each of these is expressed as a percentage, broken down by ethnicity, age and geographical area, for each calendar year 2000 to 2015.

Reoffences are only counted if they:

* are committed within one year of the offender’s previous offence (or 18 months if the case is still progressing through the courts after a year)
* lead to a court conviction, caution, reprimand or warning 

The data source is the National Offender Management Service (NOMS) Offender Equalities Statistics Bulletin – supplementary table 15.2.
summary:
* White offenders had the highest average number of reoffences per offender for every year in the time period, and committed an average of 3.3 in 2015

* all ethnic groups fell to their lowest average number of reoffences per reoffender in 2009, but since then the average number has increased for all groups
need_to_know:
Measuring true reoffending is difficult. Official records are taken from either 
the police or courts, but they underestimate the true level of reoffending. This is because not all crimes are detected and sanctioned and not all crimes and sanctions are recorded on one central system. Other methods of measuring reoffending, such as self-report studies, are likely to also underestimate the rate.

Percentage changes may not add up due to rounding of raw figures.
ethnicity_definition_summary:
For this data, the number of people counted was too small to draw any firm conclusions about specific  ethnic categories. Therefore, the data is broken down into the following broad groups: 

* White 
* Black
* Asian
* Other ethnic group
source_text: NOMS Offender Equalities Statistics Bulletin - supplementary table 15.2
data_source_purpose: Admin data used for internal management information
methodology: A certain proportion of offenders who could not be matched to the Police National Computer (PNC) are excluded from the offender cohort. Therefore, these numbers do not represent all proven offenders. Admin data sources reported as recorded. As with all large administrative data sources, some inherent inaccuracy may exist.
suppression_rules: Proportions and averages based on less than 30 offenders are removed as they make data unreliable for interpretation. Number of reoffenders, reoffences and previous offences based on less than five offenders are suppressed. This is to prevent the disclosure of individual information.

dimensions.title: Average number of reoffences per offender, by ethnicity
dimensions.summary:
* White offenders had the highest average number of reoffences per offender for every year covered by the data, and committed an average of 3.3 in 2015

* all ethnic groups fell to their lowest average number of reoffences per reoffender in 2010, but since then the average number has increased for all groups

* use caution when considering these figures and avoid direct comparisons based on them, as they don’t account for important factors

dimensions.title: Average number of reoffences per offender, by ethnicity and area
dimensions.summary:
* in 2015, the area with the highest average number of reoffences per offender was the North East, where it was 3.2

* in the North East, offenders in the Other and Asian ethnic groups committed on average 3.6 reoffences, the highest number for this region

* White and Black reoffenders have the highest average number of reoffences throughout England, except for the North East

dimensions.title: Average number of reoffences per offender, by ethnicity and age
dimensions.summary:
* in 2015, the age group with the highest average number of reoffences per offender was 10 to 14 year olds, at 3.6

* White reoffenders committed the largest number of reoffences on average for each age group between ages 18 and 39 

* Black reoffenders committed the largest number of reoffences on average for the over-39 age groups
